prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RX J1347-1145
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping RX J1347-1145 within 120"x120" to 0.13 mJy (1 sigma)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our goal is to survey the sources within the field with continuum observation. Therefore we choose the 64-input Correlator to be operated in TDM mode with dual polarization, where the maximum instantaneous IF bandwidth is 7.5 GHz.

The proposed survey field is defined as 120"x120" for RX J1347-1145, which is aligned to R.A-Dec. coordinates. This field is optimized to fully enclose the predicted critical curve of the cluster (see Fig. 1), which makes us possible to perform a complete and deep SMG survey over the entire critical curves. The field also covers the high significance region mapped by ASTE/AzTEC, where the data suggests the existence of several point sources as well as extended emissions. We will also be able to fully subtract the sources contaminated into the SZE map. According to the calculation by OT, Nyquist sampling with Band 6 at 265 GHz will require 149 pointings. This proposal focuses on to detect SMGs as point-like sources, thus only the 12-m arrays are to be used. There are no need to reconstruct large-scaled images from our multi-point observation.
The scale of 1" corresponds to 8 kpc for objects at z=3, therefore the most compact configuration (C36-1) providing angular resolution AR=1".5 and maximum angular scale MAS=11".0 will be perfect for our purpose. Moreover, since the number of sources expected to be detected within the field is estimated as 10-20, even with the lowest angular resolution of AR=1".5, we will be free from source confusions.
It is clear form the ASTE/AzTEC image (Fig. 1) that there are no strong sources to bother the imaging algorithm. To resolve any potential or serendipitous foreground contamination, such as low-z galaxies which were not resolved out in the large ASTE/AzTEC beam (30"), we set the expected largest angular scale to be 5".

We propose to survey the field uniformly as deep as 1 sigma = 0.13 mJy. It is clear form ASTE/AzTEC image (Fig. 1) that there are no strong sources to bother the sensitivity within the survey area.
With respect to the science goal of deep galaxy survey with gravitational lensing, this will provide the deepest observational constraints to the SMG source counts in the faint end at < 1 mJy, free from source confusion. The calculation discussed in Section 1.5 predicts that, with 1 sigma=0.13 mJy sensitivity, 10-20 sources are to be detected in this field to 4 sigma significance. Since the numbers strongly depend on the faint-end-slope of the real source distribution, we can strongly constrain the source model. Proposed sensitivity of 1 sigma=0.13 mJy will also enable us to construct a source-free SZE image by subtracting the detected sources with an error within a few percent of the extended signals detected at >3 sigma in the original ASTE/AzTEC map.

We set the LO frequency to 265 GHz (the highest possible frequency for band 6 receiver), which provides the bandpass for each lower and upper sidebands to be 255-259 GHz and 271-275 GHz respectively (IF=6-10 GHz). The objective for this non-standard frequency setup is to match the previous ASTE/AzTEC data, where the system bandpass was 270 +/- 30 GHz (Wilson et al. 2008). As stated in the Science Justification, we aim to combine the ALMA data with existing 270 GHz ASTE/AzTEC data. Importantly these windows are free from contamination by strong line emissions such as CO(2-1)(230 GHz).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CL0016+16
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping CL0016+16 within 90"x120" to 0.13 mJy (1 sigma)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our goal is to survey the sources within the field with continuum observation. Therefore we choose the 64-input Correlator to be operated in TDM mode with dual polarization, where the maximum instantaneous IF bandwidth is 7.5 GHz.

We set the LO frequency to 265 GHz (the highest possible frequency for band 6 receiver), which provides the bandpass for each lower and upper sidebands to be 255-259 GHz and 271-275 GHz respectively (IF=6-10 GHz). The objective for this non-standard frequency setup is to match the previous ASTE/AzTEC data, where the system bandpass was 270 +/- 30 GHz (Wilson et al. 2008). As stated in the Science Justification, we aim to combine the ALMA data with existing 270 GHz ASTE/AzTEC data. Importantly these windows are free from contamination by strong line emissions such as CO(2-1)(230 GHz).

The proposed survey field is defined as 90"x120" for CL 0016+16, which is aligned to R.A-Dec. coordinates. This field is optimized to fully enclose the predicted critical curve of the cluster (see Fig. 1), which makes us possible to perform a complete and deep SMG survey over the entire critical curves. The field also covers the high significance region mapped by ASTE/AzTEC, where the data suggests the existence of several point sources as well as extended emissions. We will also be able to fully subtract the sources contaminated into the SZE map. According to the calculation by OT, Nyquist sampling with Band 6 at 265 GHz will require 115 pointings. This proposal focuses on to detect SMGs as point sources, thus only the 12-m arrays are to be used. There are no need to reconstruct large-scaled images from our multi-point observation.
The scale of 1" corresponds to 8 kpc for objects at z=3, therefore the most compact configuration (C36-1) providing angular resolution AR=1".5 and maximum angular scale MAS=11".0 will be perfect for our purpose. Moreover, since the number of sources expected to be detected within the field is estimated as 10-20, even with the lowest angular resolution of AR=1".5, we will be free from source confusions.
It is clear form the ASTE/AzTEC image (Fig. 1) that there are no strong sources to bother the imaging algorithm. To resolve any potential or serendipitous foreground contamination, such as low-z galaxies which were not resolved out in the large ASTE/AzTEC beam (30"), we set the expected largest angular scale to be 5".

We propose to survey the field uniformly as deep as 1 sigma = 0.13 mJy. It is clear form ASTE/AzTEC image (Fig. 1) that there are no strong sources to bother the sensitivity within the survey area.
With respect to the science goal of deep galaxy survey with gravitational lensing, this will provide the deepest observational constraints to the SMG source counts in the faint end at < 1 mJy, free from source confusion. The calculation discussed in Section 1.5 predicts that, with 1 sigma=0.13 mJy sensitivity, 10-20 sources are to be detected in this field to 4 sigma significance. Since the numbers strongly depend on the faint-end-slope of the real source distribution, we can strongly constrain the source model. Proposed sensitivity of 1 sigma=0.13 mJy will also enable us to construct a source-free SZE image by subtracting the detected sources with an error within a few percent of the extended signals detected at >3 sigma in the original ASTE/AzTEC map.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Abell S0592
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping Abell S0592 within 120"x90" to 0.13 mJy (1 sigma)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our goal is to survey the sources within the field with continuum observation. Therefore we choose the 64-input Correlator to be operated in TDM mode with dual polarization, where the maximum instantaneous IF bandwidth is 7.5 GHz.

The proposed survey field is defined as 120"x90" for Abell S0592, with PA=+15 degrees (clockwise). This field is optimized to fully enclose the predicted critical curve of the cluster (see Fig. 1), which makes us possible to perform a complete and deep SMG survey over the entire critical curves. The field also covers the high significance region mapped by ASTE/AzTEC, where the data suggests the existence of several point sources as well as extended emissions. We will also be able to fully subtract the sources contaminated into the SZE map. According to the calculation by OT, Nyquist sampling with Band 6 at 265 GHz will require 115 pointings. This proposal focuses on to detect SMGs as point sources, thus only the 12-m arrays are to be used. There are no need to reconstruct large-scaled images from our multi-point observation.
The scale of 1" corresponds to 8 kpc for objects at z=3, therefore the most compact configuration (C34-1) providing angular resolution AR=1".5 and maximum angular scale MAS=11".0 will be perfect for our purpose. Moreover, since the number of sources expected to be detected within the field is estimated as 10-20, even with the lowest angular resolution of AR=1".5, we will be free from source confusions.
It is clear form the ASTE/AzTEC image (Fig. 1) that there are no strong sources to bother the imaging algorithm. To resolve any potential or serendipitous foreground contamination, such as low-z galaxies which were not resolved out in the large ASTE/AzTEC beam (30"), we set the expected largest angular scale to be 5".

We propose to survey the field uniformly as deep as 1 sigma = 0.13 mJy. It is clear form ASTE/AzTEC image (Fig. 1) that there are no strong sources to bother the sensitivity within the survey area.
With respect to the science goal of deep galaxy survey with gravitational lensing, this will provide the deepest observational constraints to the SMG source counts in the faint end at < 1 mJy, free from source confusion. The calculation discussed in Section 1.5 predicts that, with 1 sigma=0.13 mJy sensitivity, 10-20 sources are to be detected in this field to 4 sigma significance. Since the numbers strongly depend on the faint-end-slope of the real source distribution, we can strongly constrain the source model. Proposed sensitivity of 1 sigma=0.13 mJy will also enable us to construct a source-free SZE image by subtracting the detected sources with an error within a few percent of the extended signals detected at >3 sigma in the original ASTE/AzTEC map.

We set the LO frequency to 265 GHz (the highest possible frequency for band 6 receiver), which provides the bandpass for each lower and upper sidebands to be 255-259 GHz and 271-275 GHz respectively (IF=6-10 GHz). The objective for this non-standard frequency setup is to match the previous ASTE/AzTEC data, where the system bandpass was 270 +/- 30 GHz (Wilson et al. 2008). As stated in the Science Justification, we aim to combine the ALMA data with existing 270 GHz ASTE/AzTEC data. Importantly these windows are free from contamination by strong line emissions such as CO(2-1)(230 GHz).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We perform a gravitational lensing survey of Submillimeter Galaxies (SMGs) toward 3 distant clusters of galaxies selected from our ASTE/AzTEC data. Total area of 10 arcmin^2 is to be covered down to 0.13 mJy (1 sigma) at wavelength of 1.1 mm. The mean lensing amplification factor over the entire fields is ~7 and allows us to reach, on average, intrinsic fluxes of ~0.07 mJy at 4 sigma significance, comprising effectively the deepest survey ever achieved at this wavelength. We expect to detect 10-20 sources, depending on the underlying source counts of SMGs. This will not only enhance the current sample of lensed SMGs detected with ALMA by a factor of 2-3, but also enable us to constrain its faint-end shape at ~0.1 mJy. Combining with ASTE/AzTEC single dish data, the observation will further provide us the first source-free Sunyaev-Zel'dovich effect (SZE) increment images of galaxy clusters. Similar science goals were proposed for Cycle 2 (2013.1.00724.S), and ranked as grade C. We are resubmiting these since the data are not delivered yet. If the data from each field becomes available during the Cycle 2 period, there is no need to re-observe the corresponding field during Cycle 3.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00724.S 1.1 mm Survey toward Distant Lensing Clusters of Galaxies (PI: Hajime Ezawa) 2013.1.00246.S Highest Resolution Imaging of the Thermal Sunyaev-Zel'dovich Effect (PI: Tetsu Kitayama)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
